required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Relationship of Hemoglobin A1c and Diabetic Wound Healing
clinical_study.official_title: The Relationship of Hemoglobin A1c and Diabetic Wound Healing

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to investigate the relationship of hemoglobin A1c in diabetic wound healing. Additionally, a comparison of two wound dressings, AmeriGel® (Amerx Health Care Corp., Clearwater, FL) and Bacitracin, with and without vitamin C supplementation, will be done to evaluate impact on time to wound closure.

detailed_description.textblock: This is a prospective randomized controlled study evaluating the relationship of hemoglobin A1c in diabetic wound healing. Length of time for wound closure will be compared using four treatment options.

clinical_study.why_stopped: study closed due to recruitment problems

primary_outcome.time_frame: Patients are assessed every 3 months from enrollment through end of study participation, which may be 6 months
primary_outcome.description: Hgb A1c measures the average blood glucose over three months (% of hemoglobin). All subjects will be asked to get their hemoglobin A1c level at the beginning of the study and every three months for as long as they participate in the study.

secondary_outcome.measure: Length of Time for Wound Closure
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Patients are assessed every other week (bi-weekly) until 100% wound healing is achieved, which may take up to 6 months
secondary_outcome.description: Length of time for wound closure will be measured in days

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Patients are assessed every other week (bi-weekly) until 100% wound healing is achieved, which may take up to 6 months
secondary_outcome.description: Wound area measurements in length, width, and depth throughout the course of the study(measured in cm).

arm_group.description: Bacitracin wound care dressing with Vitamin C supplementation
AmeriGel® wound care dressing with Vitamin C supplementation

intervention.description: Participants will be treated with Bacitracin to their wound until 100% wound healing, which may take up to 6 months to achieve.
Participants will be treated with AmeriGel® to their wound until 100% wound healing, which may take up to 6 months to achieve.
Participants will be treated with Vitamin C supplements 1000 mg daily until 100% wound healing, which may take up to 6 months to achieve

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- >18 years of age
- Diabetic (Type I and Type II)
- Ulceration of the foot at least one centimeter in width/length
- Ulceration at least 0.2 centimeters in depth
Exclusion Criteria:
- Ulceration width/length > 7.5 centimeters
- Wound depth > 1.25 centimeters
- Purulent, excessive drainage and/or other signs of infection (i.e. erythema, edema, warmth)
- Inability to provide informed consent
- Inability to swallow pills (vitamin C supplement)
- Patients with concurrent renal problems
- Patients with medication contraindications to Vitamin C and/or topical wound dressings

facility.name: Penn State Milton S. Hershey Medical Center

reference.citation: Markuson M, Hanson D, Anderson J, Langemo D, Hunter S, Thompson P, Paulson R, Rustvang D. The relationship between hemoglobin A(1c) values and healing time for lower extremity ulcers in individuals with diabetes. Falabella A, Falanga V. Uncommon causes of ulcers. Clin Plast Surg. 1998 Jul;25(3):467-79. Review.

Lazarus GS, Cooper DM, Knighton DR, Margolis DJ, Pecoraro RE, Rodeheaver G, Robson MC. Definitions and guidelines for assessment of wounds and evaluation of healing. Arch Dermatol. 1994 Apr;130(4):489-93. Review.
Maklebust JA, Margolis D. The goodness of measurement. Adv Wound Care. 1996 May-Jun;9(3):6.

van Rijuswijl L. Wound assessment and documentation. In: Krasner LD, Rodeheaver GT, Sibbald RG (eds). Chronic Wound Care: A Clinical Source Book for Healthcare Professionals, 3rd ed. Wayne Pa: HMP Communications: 2001;101-115.

Keast DH, Bowering CK, Evans AW, Mackean GL, Burrows C, D'Souza L. MEASURE: A proposed assessment framework for developing best practice recommendations for wound assessment. Wound Repair Regen. 2004 May-Jun;12(3 Suppl):S1-17. Review.

Haslik W, Kamolz LP, Andel H, Winter W, Meissl G, Frey M. The influence of dressings and ointments on the qualitative and quantitative evaluation of burn wounds by ICG video-angiography: an experimental setup. Burns. 2004 May;30(3):232-5.
Droog EJ, Steenbergen W, Sjöberg F. Measurement of depth of burns by laser Doppler perfusion imaging. Burns. 2001 Sep;27(6):561-8.
Duckworth WC, Fawcett J, Reddy S, Page JC. Insulin-degrading activity in wound fluid. J Clin Endocrinol Metab. 2004 Feb;89(2):847-51.
Zimny S, Schatz H, Pfohl M. Determinants and estimation of healing times in diabetic foot ulcers. J Diabetes Complications. 2002 Sep-Oct;16(5):327-32.
Rubinstein A, Pierce CE Jr. Rapid healing of diabetic foot ulcers with meticulous blood glucose control. Acta Diabetol Lat. 1988 Jan-Mar;25(1):25-32.
Yue DK, McLennan S, Marsh M, Mai YW, Spaliviero J, Delbridge L, Reeve T, Turtle JR. Effects of experimental diabetes, uremia, and malnutrition on wound healing. Diabetes. 1987 Mar;36(3):295-9.
Vitamin C and the common cold. Med Lett Drugs Ther. 1970 Dec 25;12(26):105-6.

Howe GR, Hirohata T, Hislop TG, Iscovich JM, Yuan JM, Katsouyanni K, Lubin F, Marubini E, Modan B, Rohan T, et al. Dietary factors and risk of breast cancer: combined analysis of 12 case-control studies. J Natl Cancer Inst. 1990 Apr 4;82(7):561-9.
Wassertheil-Smoller S, Romney SL, Wylie-Rosett J, Slagle S, Miller G, Lucido D, Duttagupta C, Palan PR. Dietary vitamin C and uterine cervical dysplasia. Am J Epidemiol. 1981 Nov;114(5):714-24.

Snyder RJ, Kirsner RS, Warriner RA 3rd, Lavery LA, Hanft JR, Sheehan P. Consensus recommendations on advancing the standard of care for treating neuropathic foot ulcers in patients with diabetes. Ostomy Wound Manage. 2010 Apr;56(4 Suppl):S1-24.
Pollack SV. Wound healing: a review. III. Nutritional factors affecting wound healing. J Dermatol Surg Oncol. 1979 Aug;5(8):615-9.

van Anholt RD, Sobotka L, Meijer EP, Heyman H, Groen HW, Topinková E, van Leen M, Schols JM. Specific nutritional support accelerates pressure ulcer healing and reduces wound care intensity in non-malnourished patients. Nutrition. 2010 Sep;26(9):867-72. doi: 10.1016/j.nut.2010.05.009. Epub 2010 Jul 3.
Smith RG. Validation of Wagner's classification: a literature review. Ostomy Wound Manage. 2003 Jan;49(1):54-62. Review.

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Two subjects were screened and enrolled at the clinic site on 2/24/2012 and 1/14/2013.

group.title: Bacitracin Wound Care Dressing Alone
group.description: Bacitracin wound care dressing alone Bacitracin: Participants will be treated with Bacitracin to their wound until 100% wound healing, which may take up to 6 months to achieve. Hemoglobin A1c: Hemoglobin A1c levels will be performed and reviewed every three months to assess its relationship to wound healing

group.description: Bacitracin wound care dressing with Vitamin C supplementation Bacitracin: Participants will be treated with Bacitracin to their wound until 100% wound healing, which may take up to 6 months to achieve. group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

outcome.title: Hgb A1c Level
outcome.description: Hgb A1c measures the average blood glucose over three months (% of hemoglobin). All subjects will be asked to get their hemoglobin A1c level at the beginning of the study and every three months for as long as they participate in the study.
outcome.time_frame: Patients are assessed every 3 months from enrollment through end of study participation, which may be 6 months
outcome.population: Enrollment and 3-month visit A1c levels were obtained for the subject in the Bacitracin with Vit C arm. Enrollment A1c level was obtained for the AmeriGel would care dressing alone. However, this subject withdrew from the study before 3-month A1c level was obtained.

measure.title: Hgb A1c Level
measure.description: Hgb A1c measures the average blood glucose over three months (% of hemoglobin). All subjects will be asked to get their hemoglobin A1c level at the beginning of the study and every three months for as long as they participate in the study.
measure.population: Enrollment and 3-month visit A1c levels were obtained for the subject in the Bacitracin with Vit C arm. Enrollment A1c level was obtained for the AmeriGel would care dressing alone. However, this subject withdrew from the study before 3-month A1c level was obtained.

measurement_list.measurement: A1c not taken - patient withdrawn from study prior to 3 months

outcome.title: Length of Time for Wound Closure
outcome.description: Length of time for wound closure will be measured in days
outcome.time_frame: Patients are assessed every other week (bi-weekly) until 100% wound healing is achieved, which may take up to 6 months
outcome.population: Only the subject in the Bacitracin with Vit C arm achieved would healing. The subject in the AmeriGel would care dressing alone arm was withdrawn due to lack of healing and infection.

measure.title: Length of Time for Wound Closure
measure.description: Length of time for wound closure will be measured in days
measure.population: Only the subject in the Bacitracin with Vit C arm achieved would healing. The subject in the AmeriGel would care dressing alone arm was withdrawn due to lack of healing and infection.

outcome.title: Wound Area Measurements
outcome.description: Wound area measurements in length, width, and depth throughout the course of the study(measured in cm).
outcome.time_frame: Patients are assessed every other week (bi-weekly) until 100% wound healing is achieved, which may take up to 6 months
outcome.population: The subject enrolled in Bacitracin with Vit C arm had measurements of the wound (width, depth, length) recorded beginning at week 0 through week 20. The subject enrolled in the AmeriGel wound care dressing alone had measurements recorded of the wound (width, depth, length) beginning at week 0 through week 2 before withdrawing from the study.

event.description: Wound infection at 2 weeks; patient withdrawn from study and provided standard of care treatment to include antibiotics.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: Study terminated due to recruitment issues - only two subjects enrolled in study.

point_of_contact.organization: Penn State Milton S. Hershey Medical Center
